headline: Trump says Coke will shift to cane sugar. But increasingly, shoppers want no sugar in their sodas
summary: The debate over whether Coca-Cola should use high-fructose corn syrup or cane sugar in its signature soda obscures an important fact: Consumers are increasingly looking for Coke with no sugar at all.  Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which was introduced in 2017, uses both the artificial sweetener aspartame and the natural sweetener stevia in its recipe.  The scrutiny over Coke’s sweeteners began Wednesday, when President Donald Trump announced that Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Co. had agreed to switch to using cane sugar in the regular version of its beverage manufactured in the U.S.

raw.headline: Trump says Coke will shift to cane sugar. But increasingly, shoppers want no sugar in their sodas

Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which was introduced in 2017, uses both the artificial sweetener aspartame and the natural sweetener stevia in its recipe.  The scrutiny over Coke’s sweeteners began Wednesday, when President Donald Trump announced that Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Co. had agreed to switch to using cane sugar in the regular version of its beverage manufactured in the U.S.

headline: Coke's shift to cane sugar would be expensive, hurt US farmers
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -A possible move by Coca-Cola , and other beverage and food industries, to use cane sugar instead of corn syrup as a sweetener would be difficult and expensive to implement, while mostly negative for farmers in the United States.  U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that Coca-Cola had agreed to use cane sugar in its beverages in the country after his discussions with the maker of the top soda pop brand.  Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and activists from his Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) campaign have been pushing for changes in ingredients used by the food and beverage industry, claiming the proposed substitutes are healthier.

raw.headline: Coke's shift to cane sugar would be expensive, hurt US farmers
raw.summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -A possible move by Coca-Cola , and other beverage and food industries, to use cane sugar instead of corn syrup as a sweetener would be difficult and expensive to implement, while mostly negative for farmers in the United States.  U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that Coca-Cola had agreed to use cane sugar in its beverages in the country after his discussions with the maker of the top soda pop brand.  Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and activists from his Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) campaign have been pushing for changes in ingredients used by the food and beverage industry, claiming the proposed substitutes are healthier.

headline: PepsiCo to rebrand Lay's, Tostitos without artificial dyes, flavors
summary: (Reuters) -PepsiCo  is planning to highlight what will no longer be in its potato or tortilla chips - artificial colors or flavors - when it re-launches its Lay's and Tostitos brands later this year, executives said on Thursday.  The overhaul for the company's top-selling snack brands comes as U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pushes Americans to eat "whole foods" and pressures manufacturers to ditch dyes.  U.S. food makers have been announcing plans to remove dyes from their products and introduce new ones without the colors under pressure from Kennedy and the Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) social movement backing him.

raw.headline: PepsiCo to rebrand Lay's, Tostitos without artificial dyes, flavors
raw.summary: (Reuters) -PepsiCo  is planning to highlight what will no longer be in its potato or tortilla chips - artificial colors or flavors - when it re-launches its Lay's and Tostitos brands later this year, executives said on Thursday.  The overhaul for the company's top-selling snack brands comes as U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pushes Americans to eat "whole foods" and pressures manufacturers to ditch dyes.  U.S. food makers have been announcing plans to remove dyes from their products and introduce new ones without the colors under pressure from Kennedy and the Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) social movement backing him.

headline: ADM, Ingredion Stocks Fall After Trump Says Coke Will Ditch Corn Syrup
summary: President Trump said Coca-Cola (KO) will go back to using cane sugar in its namesake soda, following criticism of sweeteners such as high-fructose corn syrup by Trump’s health secretary. Shares of both Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) and Ingredion (INGR), which supply corn syrup, fell Thursday.

headline: What PepsiCo's CEO says about consumers & earnings
summary: PepsiCo (PEP) is seeing a lift after cutting guidance just last quarter and focusing on more affordable, smaller-sized products. Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi spoke with CEO Ramon Laguarta about possible cost cuts, pressure to break up the business, and how Pepsi is responding to Trump's push for real sugar in soft drinks — a move Coca-Cola (KO) hasn't confirmed. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Trump & Coca-Cola, Novartis earnings, Netflix preview: Trending Tickers
summary: President Trump says Coca-Cola (KO) will switch to real cane sugar in US drinks, though the company has yet to confirm, pressuring corn futures and shares of companies that make corn syrup including ADM (ADM) and Ingredion (INGR). Novartis (NVS) reported a second quarter earnings beat and announced a $10 billion buyback. The company also revealed its CFO is retiring, and sales of a key drug disappointed. Netflix (NFLX) reports earnings after the bell, with strong revenue and profit growth expected as investors weigh high expectations and valuation. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief: Market Sunrise here.

headline: PepsiCo's results exceed expectations on international growth, soda demand rebound
summary: (Reuters) -PepsiCo reported better-than-expected quarterly results on Thursday, driven by steady demand for its sodas and snacks in the U.S. and other major markets, including Europe.  The Gatorade owner sounded a more upbeat tone in its comments this quarter, after previously warning that heightened macro and consumer uncertainties could be a drag on its business in the U.S. and some international markets this year.  "Our business remained resilient during the second quarter, navigating through a complex geopolitical and macroeconomic environment," PepsiCo executives said in a statement.

raw.headline: PepsiCo's results exceed expectations on international growth, soda demand rebound
raw.summary: (Reuters) -PepsiCo reported better-than-expected quarterly results on Thursday, driven by steady demand for its sodas and snacks in the U.S. and other major markets, including Europe.  The Gatorade owner sounded a more upbeat tone in its comments this quarter, after previously warning that heightened macro and consumer uncertainties could be a drag on its business in the U.S. and some international markets this year.  "Our business remained resilient during the second quarter, navigating through a complex geopolitical and macroeconomic environment," PepsiCo executives said in a statement.

headline: Trump: I'm getting Coca-Cola to change its recipe
summary: STORY: Donald Trump is not happy with his Coca-Cola, and he’s doing something about it.The U.S. President says he’s persuaded the company to change the recipe for its famous drink.Trump says executives have agreed to use cane sugar in the U.S., instead of corn syrup.“You’ll see”, he said in a social media post, “it’s just better!”Medical experts say there’s no real health advantage in cane sugar.However, a panel convened by Trump has said corn syrup could play a role in childhood obesity and other conditions.Nutritionists generally just advise limiting the intake of all sugars.Now farmers may not be happy about any change.A corn industry body said a move to avoid syrup could cost thousands of American jobs.It said the result would be more imports of sugar, for no health benefit.Coca-Cola said it would share details on new offerings soon, and thanked Trump for his interest in its products.Whenever a change comes, president seems sure to be ready with a taste test.

raw.headline: Trump: I'm getting Coca-Cola to change its recipe
raw.summary: STORY: Donald Trump is not happy with his Coca-Cola, and he’s doing something about it.The U.S. President says he’s persuaded the company to change the recipe for its famous drink.Trump says executives have agreed to use cane sugar in the U.S., instead of corn syrup.“You’ll see”, he said in a social media post, “it’s just better!”Medical experts say there’s no real health advantage in cane sugar.However, a panel convened by Trump has said corn syrup could play a role in childhood obesity and other conditions.Nutritionists generally just advise limiting the intake of all sugars.Now farmers may not be happy about any change.A corn industry body said a move to avoid syrup could cost thousands of American jobs.It said the result would be more imports of sugar, for no health benefit.Coca-Cola said it would share details on new offerings soon, and thanked Trump for his interest in its products.Whenever a change comes, president seems sure to be ready with a taste test.
